articles.headline: Tough Choices, and Criticism, for Emily’s List as Democratic Women Flood Primaries
articles.snippet: For Democratic women, no endorsement is as powerful as one from the fund-raising juggernaut. But with so many female candidates, the group is forced to pick between them.
articles.abstract: For Democratic women, no endorsement is as powerful as one from the fund-raising juggernaut. But with so many female candidates, the group is forced to pick between them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the night before she announced her candidacy for governor, Stacey Evans got a telephone call from Emily’s List, the fund-raising juggernaut that has helped elect hundreds of Democratic women who support abortion rights. It was not a happy conversation.

articles.headline: Facebook Adds A.I. Labs in Seattle and Pittsburgh, Pressuring Local Universities
articles.snippet: Salaries for artificial intelligence researchers at big tech companies are skyrocketing, luring many professors.
articles.abstract: Salaries for artificial intelligence researchers at big tech companies are skyrocketing, luring many professors.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At a conference in Silicon Valley this week, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, vowed that his company would “keep building” despite a swirl of questions around the way it has dealt with misinformation and the personal data of its users.

articles.headline: Jobless Rate Looks Like Old Times, but the Economy Doesn’t
articles.snippet: With unemployment below 4 percent for the first time since 2000, the recovery’s duration is remarkable, but lagging pay remains a riddle.
articles.abstract: With unemployment below 4 percent for the first time since 2000, the recovery’s duration is remarkable, but lagging pay remains a riddle.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time the unemployment rate fell below the 4 percent threshold was in 2000, during a period of frenetic activity remembered as the dot-com boom.

articles.headline: Citing ‘Crisis of Confidence,’ Academy Calls Off Nobel Literature Prize
articles.snippet: The decision to postpone the award for a year amid a sexual misconduct scandal marked an extraordinary public reckoning for the 232-year-old organization.
articles.abstract: The decision to postpone the award for a year amid a sexual misconduct scandal marked an extraordinary public reckoning for the 232-year-old organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Faced with a sexual-abuse  scandal, accusations of financial wrongdoing and hints of a cover-up, the Swedish Academy announced on Friday that for the first time in 69 years it would postpone awarding the Nobel Prize in Literature.
articles.byline: By Christina Anderson and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: He Wrote Disturbing Plans for a School Shooting. But Was That a Crime?
articles.snippet: After residents reported a man who worried them, a journal turned up. “I’m aiming to kill as many as I can,” it read. But that wasn’t the end of the story.
articles.abstract: After residents reported a man who worried them, a journal turned up. “I’m aiming to kill as many as I can,” it read. But that wasn’t the end of the story.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAIR HAVEN, Vt. — When people who knew Jack Sawyer saw something, they said something.

articles.headline: Trump Is Said to Have Known of Payment to Stormy Daniels Months Before He Denied It
articles.snippet: How much the president knew about the $130,000 payment to the porn actress and who else was aware of it have been at the center of a swirling controversy for the past 48 hours.
articles.abstract: How much the president knew about the $130,000 payment to the porn actress and who else was aware of it have been at the center of a swirling controversy for the past 48 hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump knew about a six-figure payment that Michael D. Cohen, his personal lawyer, made to a pornographic film actress several months before he denied any knowledge of it to reporters aboard Air Force One in April, according to two people familiar with the arrangement.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman, Jim Rutenberg and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Patagonia v. Trump
articles.snippet: The outdoor retailer has supported grass-roots environmental activists for decades. Now it is suing the president in a bid to protect Bears Ears National Monument.
articles.abstract: The outdoor retailer has supported grass-roots environmental activists for decades. Now it is suing the president in a bid to protect Bears Ears National Monument.
articles.lead_paragraph: VENTURA, Calif. — The offices of Patagonia occupy a low-slung complex of stucco buildings in this sleepy beachside town in Southern California. There are solar panels and picnic tables in the parking lot, day care with a jungle gym by the main lobby and easy access to the beach, where employees surf during lunch break. It is a corporate Eden of sorts, where idealistic Californians run a privately held company that sells about $1 billion of puffy down jackets and organic cotton jeans each year.

articles.headline: As State Lawmaker Claims Abuse, Party Leaders Shield Her Colleague
articles.snippet: In Pennsylvania, a female House member has a protective order against a male colleague she accuses of sexual abuse. Party leaders have made no move to expel him.
articles.abstract: In Pennsylvania, a female House member has a protective order against a male colleague she accuses of sexual abuse. Party leaders have made no move to expel him.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARRISBURG, Pa. — When she is 10 minutes from the Pennsylvania Statehouse, Representative Tarah Toohil phones the sergeant-at-arms. A security officer then meets her in the parking garage and escorts her to her office. He hovers at her elbow all day, during committee hearings, debates and votes.

articles.headline: At His Ranch, John McCain Shares Memories and Regrets With Friends
articles.snippet: Mr. McCain urged former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to “not walk away” from politics, and said he wished he had chosen Joseph I. Lieberman, not Sarah Palin, as his running mate in 2008.
articles.abstract: Mr. McCain urged former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to “not walk away” from politics, and said he wished he had chosen Joseph I. Lieberman, not Sarah Palin, as his running mate in 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — When former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. traveled to Senator John McCain’s Arizona ranch last Sunday to spend a few hours with his ailing friend, the two reminisced about the “crazy senators” they had served with, the overseas trips they took together for decades and the friendship Mr. McCain forged with Mr. Biden’s two sons.

articles.headline: How Michael Cohen, Trump’s Fixer, Built a Shadowy Business Empire
articles.snippet: Michael Cohen’s ventures spanned taxis, a casino boat, real estate and ethanol. Many had links to the former Soviet Union. Now a federal inquiry threatens not just Mr. Cohen, but also the White House.
articles.abstract: Michael Cohen’s ventures spanned taxis, a casino boat, real estate and ethanol. Many had links to the former Soviet Union. Now a federal inquiry threatens not just Mr. Cohen, but also the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was a personal-injury lawyer who often worked out of taxi offices scattered around New York City.
articles.byline: By William K. Rashbaum, Danny Hakim, Brian M. Rosenthal, Emily Flitter and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Yes, It’s Bad. Robocalls, and Their Scams, Are Surging.
articles.snippet: The volume of automated phone calls has skyrocketed this year over last, according to a service that tracks them, and complaints have also risen sharply.
articles.abstract: The volume of automated phone calls has skyrocketed this year over last, according to a service that tracks them, and complaints have also risen sharply.

articles.headline: An Urgent Debate for California Republicans: How to Get Back in the Game
articles.snippet: Hitting rock bottom? California Republicans fear that they will have no candidate for U.S. senator or governor on the ballot in November.
articles.abstract: Hitting rock bottom? California Republicans fear that they will have no candidate for U.S. senator or governor on the ballot in November.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHITTIER, Calif. — For anyone wondering about the state of the Republican Party in California these days, consider this: There may be no Republican candidate for governor or United States senator on the state’s ballot this November.

articles.headline: Meet the Pro-Trade, Pro-Immigration Economist Running for Congress. As a Republican. In Ohio.
articles.snippet: Tim Kane would seem to have the right stuff to be a G.O.P. candidate for Congress in any other year. But in 2018, he seems out of step with his party.
articles.abstract: Tim Kane would seem to have the right stuff to be a G.O.P. candidate for Congress in any other year. But in 2018, he seems out of step with his party.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — When Pat Tiberi announced last fall that he was retiring after representing Ohio’s 12th Congressional District for almost two decades, there was a long line of fellow Republicans waiting to replace him. The party’s primary on Tuesday will feature 10 candidates, including two state senators, a county prosecutor and a local conservative activist.

articles.headline: Trump Says He Got Rid of Obamacare. The I.R.S. Doesn’t Agree.
articles.snippet: The I.R.S. has started sending penalty notices to businesses that failed to comply with the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate, angering Republicans and business groups.
articles.abstract: The I.R.S. has started sending penalty notices to businesses that failed to comply with the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate, angering Republicans and business groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a rally in Michigan a little over a week ago, President Trump assured his supporters that he had kept his promise to abolish the Affordable Care Act — even though Congress had failed to repeal the Obama-era health law.

articles.headline: Is This Ad ‘Relevant to the Trump Voter?’ Advertisers Are Asking
articles.snippet: At least one ad agency has deployed strategists to immerse themselves in swing-state cities to gain a better understanding of a broader range of consumers.
articles.abstract: At least one ad agency has deployed strategists to immerse themselves in swing-state cities to gain a better understanding of a broader range of consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The commercial for HP features a large family enjoying Christmas dinner together — that is, until the words “global warming” are uttered. A heated exchange between two sisters follows, culminating in one shouting at the other to leave her house.

articles.headline: Scholars Have Data on Millions of Facebook Users. Who’s Guarding It?
articles.snippet: Academics have scoured Facebook pages in the name of science. But the troves they’ve amassed are sometimes unsecured and now pose a privacy risk.
articles.abstract: Academics have scoured Facebook pages in the name of science. But the troves they’ve amassed are sometimes unsecured and now pose a privacy risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In July 2014, a team of four Swedish and Polish researchers began using an automated program to better understand what people posted on Facebook.

articles.headline: Verifying the End of a Nuclear North Korea ‘Could Make Iran Look Easy’
articles.snippet: Inspections to confirm that North Korea had shut down its nuclear program and secure its arms would be far more onerous than those in Iran under a current deal that President Trump wants to end.
articles.abstract: Inspections to confirm that North Korea had shut down its nuclear program and secure its arms would be far more onerous than those in Iran under a current deal that President Trump wants to end.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As he weighs opening nuclear disarmament negotiations with North Korea, President Trump faces a regime that for decades has hidden key elements of its nuclear programs from international monitors and has banned inspectors from the country.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: In Fight Against Violent Crime, Justice Dept. Targets Low-Level Gun Offenders
articles.snippet: Attorney General Jeff Sessions’s aggressive enforcement has set off a debate about whether his approach is the most effective way to fight gun crimes.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Jeff Sessions’s aggressive enforcement has set off a debate about whether his approach is the most effective way to fight gun crimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bobby Amos stood outside of an Episcopal church in Alabama last spring, begging police to kill him. He had been suicidal earlier and held a gun to his head, his wife said, and she had hidden the weapon at the church, where he had followed her to retrieve it.

articles.headline: Trump Weighs In on West Virginia Senate Race in Sign of Republican Anxiety
articles.snippet: The president tweeted that Don Blankenship’s opponents have a better chance of beating the incumbent Democratic senator, Joe Manchin.
articles.abstract: The president tweeted that Don Blankenship’s opponents have a better chance of beating the incumbent Democratic senator, Joe Manchin.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump intervened Monday in the West Virginia Republican Senate primary, pleading with voters a day before the election to oppose the former mine operator Don Blankenship, and signaling Republican anxiety over the prospect of forfeiting yet another red-state Senate race.
